def_cn: (表示曾经相信、希望或期待)将，将会
def_en: You use would when you are saying what someone believed, hoped, or expected to happen or be the case.

def_cn: (表示曾经打算)将，将会
def_en: You use would when saying what someone intended to do.

def_cn: (表示可能出现的情况的结果或影响)会，将会
def_en: You use would when you are referring to the result or effect of a possible situation.

def_cn: (would 或 would have 与过去分词连用，表示有充分理由认为或猜测是某种情况)肯定，一定，应该
def_en: You use would, or would have with a past participle, to indicate that you are assuming or guessing that something is true, because you have good reasons for thinking it.

def_cn: (用于if，unless等引导的条件状语从句的主句，表示认为某事不大可能发生)就，该
def_en: You use would in the main clause of some 'if' and 'unless' sentences to indicate something you consider to be fairly unlikely to happen.

def_cn: 肯;愿意
def_en: You use would to say that someone was willing to do something. You use would not to indicate that they refused to do something.

def_cn: (表示尽管付出很大努力却没有发生)就(不)，偏(不)
def_en: You use would not to indicate that something did not happen, often in spite of a lot of effort.

def_cn: (尤与like, love 和 wish 连用，表示想做某事或拥有某物，或希望某事发生)要，会
def_en: You use would, especially with 'like', 'love', and 'wish', when saying that someone wants to do or have a particular thing or wants a particular thing to happen.  would rather→see: rather;

def_cn: (用于带if从句的疑问句中，表示请求许可做某事)会
def_en: You use would with 'if' clauses in questions when you are asking for permission to do something.

def_cn: (通常在疑问句中与 like 连用，表示礼貌地给予或邀请)
def_en: You use would, usually in questions with 'like', when you are making a polite offer or invitation.

def_cn: (通常用于疑问句中，表示礼貌地请求某人做某事)请
def_en: You use would, usually in questions, when you are politely asking someone to do something.

def_cn: (用于批评，表示对某人做某事并不感到意外，此时 would 须重读)
def_en: You say that someone would do something when it is typical of them and you are critical of it. You emphasize the word would when you use it in this way.

def_cn: (would 或 would have 与过去分词连用，表示发表看法或了解他人是否赞同自己的看法，尤用于对自己的话没有把握时)
def_en: You use would, or sometimes would have with a past participle, when you are expressing your opinion about something or seeing if people agree with you, especially when you are uncertain about what you are saying.

def_cn: (用于以随便的口气向人提出建议)我(就)会
def_en: You use I would when you are giving someone advice in an informal way.

def_cn: (用于否定句，与 guess, know 等动词连用，表示某事不明显，尤用于某事令人吃惊时)
def_en: You use you would in negative sentences with verbs such as 'guess' and 'know' when you want to say that something is not obvious, especially something surprising.

def_cn: (表示某事过去惯常发生, 而现在不再发生了)就，会
def_en: You use would to talk about something which happened regularly in the past but which no longer happens.

def_cn: (would have 与过去分词连用，表示某个时间前可能发生的事情)就，会
def_en: You use would have with a past participle when you are saying what was likely to have happened by a particular time.

def_cn: (would have 与过去分词连用，表示过去可能发生的事情的结果或影响)就，会
def_en: You use would have with a past participle when you are referring to the result or effect of a possible event in the past.

def_cn: 原想;本来想
def_en: If you say that someone would have liked or preferred something, you mean that they wanted to do it or have it but were unable to.

def_cn: (通常用于否定句，批评某人所为，表示不满)（不）会
def_en: You use would, usually in negative sentences, to criticize something that someone has done and to express your disapproval of it.

def_cn: 但愿
def_en: If you say 'would that' something were the case, you are saying that you wish it were the case.
